This way there can be, like, a normal difficulty curve.
I can only imagine how many people went the wrong way in DS1 and got destroyed by skeletons or ghosts. That's not a fun experience.
Like, the areas are big and you can go down different paths within then, rather than going to completely different zones.
The lack of nonlinearity in DS3 is a little disappointing, but it is also absolutely a good design decision. Especially early on.
The cathedral is probably my favorite area so far. Really captures that specific medieval mood and element of cautious exportation.
How can you get anywhere in any souls game and not be certifiably paranoid about ambushes at all times. Doesn't make sense.
Like I find the regular enemies that are big and fast and aggressive annoying to deal with. But the ambushes in the cathedral? Pffffffffffff
I'm still not used to, like, being good at a game that most people find hard. I'm always on the other end of that.
It's always funny to read about people having trouble with things that you just breezed right through.
I'm looking forward to trying out a dex and int build later. The way spells work seems much more interesting now.
On some level I'm sad that the big fat armored knight with a giant shield play style is dead, but it had a good run.
@ran_num @maikantopia @AtlusUSA I'm sad that Dante didn't make the cut : (

Dark Souls 3

Is good.

God I just love Melville's writing so much sometimes.
"But there were some boobies and bumpkins there, who, by their intense greenness: must have come from the heart and centre of all verdure."
That is an amazing way of describing not being tired anymore late at night.
"What little nappishness remained in us altogether departed" #moby-dick
Bleh, I need to get a new job. I love my current one but it just doesn't pay well enough : (
My early PC rqgs are like Fallout or even older shit like Realms. The ones with real time combat never hit with me.
I didn't like Pillars of Eternity but that's because it was a nostalgia project aimed slightly off from my childhood.
It's so nice when a kickstarter game turns out good. The only real disappointment I've backed was probably Banner Saga.
Like it looks like it was practically a romhack of Link to the Past at first. Now it's practically unrecognizable.
It's funny watching the Hyper Light Drifter pitch video because they clearly threw out all the gameplay mechanics except the dash.
So beating your head against a difficult bit feels like self improvement rather than just gambling.
That's one area where HLD is really similar to a souls game: it feels fundamentally fair.
